Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) The ORR polarization curves on the Pt3M (M = La, Zr, Ti, Ni, and Co) alloy nanocatalysts and pure Pt nanocatalyst [36], (b) Kinetic current density (j k) a t 0.95 V for ORR on the Pt3M (M = La, Zr, Ti, Ni, and Co) alloy nanocatalysts and pure Pt nanocatalyst electrodes in a 0.1 M HClO4 solution, as a function of the measured d-band centers [36], (c) Specific activities at 0.95 V and improvement factors versus Pt catalysts [36], Copyright 2015 Elsevier. (d) Electrochemical characterization of Pt3Y films sputtered onto GDL from alloy targets. The activity of Pt3Y at 0.7 V is twice that of sputtered Pt [39]. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a–e) Catalytic activity maps of five different Pt3Y-YO3 surfaces. The position of the superficial O (Y) atoms is indicated with red (gray) dots. The red line indicates the size of the simulation cell. The arrows in the top-left scale bar indicate the catalytic activity of two reference systems, Pt (111) and Pt-skin Pt3Y (111), (f) Volcano plot for ORR relative to pure Pt (111). The surface type (A–E) correspond to the activity maps shown in Fig. 3(a–e) [40]. Copyright 2018 Elsevier. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) Linear scanning voltammetry curve with scanning rate of 10 mV s−1, (b) Mass activity, (c) Specific activity, (d) Chrono current curve of Com Pt/C and synthesized PtCe/C catalysts at different annealing temperatures [42]. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) According to the composition obtained by deconvolution of Pd 3d peak in XPS spectrum, the area of metal Pd and Pd oxide is compared, (b) The Tafel slope diagram of Pd/C, Pd4Ir/C and Pd Ir based alloy catalysts, (c) Initial half wave potential (E 1/2, i) and difference between initial half wave potential (E 1/2, i) and final half wave potential after 50 cycles (E 1/2, f) for Pd/C, Pd4Ir/C, and Pd-Ir-based ternary alloy catalysts showing ORR activity [62]. Rare earth (RE) metals have special 4f shell electronic configuration and special physical and chemical properties. Therefore, rare-earth-based catalysts are extensive used in the electrochemical cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. However, the low conductivity and low active site density of these catalysts limit their effective application in electrochemistry. The results show that the oxygen reduction activity and stability of rare-earth-based catalysts can be significantly improved by controlling the electronic structure and spatial configuration of active sites through doping of metal/nonmetal elements. In this paper, the main research work on metal/nonmetallic element doping to improve the performance of rare earth-based-catalysts in recent years was reviewed, including noble metal element doping, non-noble metal element doping, non-metallic element doping, perovskite and so on. The paper further summarized and pointed out the problems and challenges faced by rare-earth-based catalysts, and looked forward to their development prospects and future research directions. Graphical abstract In recent years, rare earth metals have been widely used in the electrochemical cathodic oxygen reduction (ORR) of fuel cells because of their special 4f shell electronic structure and special physical and chemical properties. However, the low conductivity and low active site density of these catalysts limit their effective application in electrochemistry. The results show that the electronic structure and spatial configuration of the active sites can be significantly improved by doping metal/non-metal elements, which can significantly improve the oxygen reduction activity and stability of the rare-earth based catalysts. In this paper, the main research work on improving the performance of rare earth-based catalysts doped with metal/non-metal elements at home and abroad in recent years is reviewed, and their development prospects and future prospects are also prospected. However, due to rapid population growth and the improvement of human living standards, people rely excessively on fossil fuels, resulting in a series of problems such as energy shortage and environmental pollution [1]. In order to address these issues, it is critical to discover environment-friendly and sustainable new strength sources, in which fuel cell is an essential improvement object [2,3]. Fuel cells are characterized by their uncommon perspectives as future energy devices and to solve several long-standing thorny problems. It is considered to be the most influential and clean energy conversion device. The fuel reacts with oxygen through a mild electrochemical process without burning. The whole gas conversion effectivity is no longer limited with the aid of the Carnot cycle [4,5]. However, the overall performance of fuel cells is nevertheless hindered by means of the gradual dynamics of ORR. ORR is extensively used in superior oxidation system by way of in-situ hydrogen peroxide electrogeneration. Oxygen can be decreased to hydrogen peroxide the use of two electron pathways or to water the usage of 4 electron pathways in an aggressive way. At present, noble metal catalysts (such as Pt) are the latest and most efficient electrocatalysts of ORR. However, its commercial application is affected by its high cost, high load, low abundance, toxic effect and short life [6-8]. According to the 2020 fuel cell target of the United States Department of Energy (DOE), the load of platinum group metals (PGM) should not exceed 0.125 g/kW, which makes the MEA area load 0.125 mg/cm2, assuming a rated power of 1.0 W/cm2 [9]. Therefore, the lookup on ORR catalyst with low cost, excessive effectivity and remarkable balance has been broadly studied [10,11]. Rare earth metals have attracted large interest due to their one-of-a-kind bodily and chemical homes of 4f shell digital configuration [12]. Rare earth metals have strong coordination ability with reactant molecular orbitals, while rare earth oxides have the characteristics of oxygen affinity and valence state changes. Oxygen vacancies are relatively easy to form and are often used as co catalysts in redox reactions. They can protect the high catalytic active sites of the main catalyst and transfer O species to the active sites during the redox reaction [13,14]. In the 1970s, LaNi5 was the first to use hydrogen cathodic electrophoresis and produce reaction [15], which is the first application of rare earth metals in electrocatalysis. In recent years, La2O3, CeO2, Y2O3 and other rare earth oxides have been applied widely in oxygen reduction catalysts due to their special electronic structure, good conductivity, stable stability and outstanding ORR electrocatalytic activity [16]. As a relatively independent class of elements on the periodic table, the electronic configuration of rare earth elements is 4f special [17]. As the atomic number increases, the electrons are gradually added to the 4f orbital, not the 5 s and 5d orbital [18]. These one-of-a-kind fillers make uncommon rare earth factors exhibit a sequence of specific houses in the formation of compounds or different materials. This paper in the main discusses the usual function of rare earth factors in rare-earth-primarily based substances by means of forming heterostructure interfaces, doping/substitution engineering, stress impact and different methods to decorate the pastime of substances (Scheme 1 ). From the viewpoint of simulation, the interior approach of catalysis belongs to the technique of adsorption, conversion and desorption, and these constituent methods are well related to specific digital structures. Since electronic structures affect the strong potential barrier and internal movement of the catalyst, these features of rare earth-based substances can additionally information us to higher recognize the electrocatalysis of uncommon earth elements. In this paper, the research results of rare-earth-based catalysts are briefly described and summarized, and the development prospect of rare earth based electrocatalytic materials is prospected, which presents a lookup route for the complicated characterization, high-quality synthesis and environment friendly discovery of uncommon earth based totally electrocatalytic materials. 2 The mechanism of oxygen reduction The occurrence of cathode reaction of fuel cell depends on oxygen reduction reaction, and the occurrence of oxygen reduction reaction requires high overpotential, which greatly limits the working process of fuel cell. Therefore, improving the over-potential condition and improving the kinetic properties of oxygen reduction reaction is one of the keys to improve the performance of fuel cells. However, the reaction mechanism is still unclear. At present, oxygen reduction reaction is considered as a multi-electron transfer path. It is usually classified into: two steps according to the number of electron transfer: one is two electron transfer processes and the other is four electron transfer processes. Usually, the electron transfer number (n) and H2O2 yield can be determined by rotating the ring disk electrode. The occurrence of the double electron process can also be verified by the occurrence of the Fenton reaction. In the dual electron process, the presence of intermediate products is not conducive to the cathodic catalysis of fuel cells, but it can be used as a synthesis method for hydrogen peroxide. Compared with traditional H2O2 synthesis methods, this method is safer, more environmentally friendly, and more convenient. In addition, reasonable control of H2O2 generated through dual electron ORR channels can be used to treat severely polluted water. According to kinetics, the catalytic process only transfers one electron at a time. In addition, several steps of the ORR mechanism are affected by the pH value of the electrolyte solution. In order to eliminate the influence of pH on the external potential, researchers usually use a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) as a reference electrode. The ORR equation for active sites in acidic electrolyte solutions is as follows: (1) * + O2 + H+ + e− → HOO* (2) HOO* + O2 + H+ + e− → O* + H2O (3) O* + H+ + e− → OH* (4) OH* + H+ + e− → H2O The total reaction is: (5) O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O The ORR mechanism of active sites in alkaline electrolyte solutions is as follows: (6) * + O2 + H2O + e− → HOO* + OH− (7) HOO* + e− → O* + OH− (8) O* + H2O + e− → OH* + OH− (9) OH* + e− → OH− + * The total reaction is: (10) O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH− Rare-earth-based catalysts have developed into a novel research part in the field of electrocatalysis due to unique electronic composition (The coupling between 4f orbits and valence orbits, the coordination environment is unsaturated and the unique behavior as a load transport bridge). The interaction between rare earth elements and active sites can be obtained by electronic strain effect. Configuration, local geometric distortion is exposed at the active site, and lead to the formation of electronic conductors with heterostructures. In the process of electrocatalysis, stress effect, mixing/ replacement, interface technology and monoatomicity are the appropriate adjustment mechanisms of rare earth species. These modulation mechanisms are intently associated to the exclusive digital shape of rare earth elements, such as 4f band occupation and 5d band cavitation. To effectively utilize the unique electronic structure of rare-earth based materials to enhance their intrinsic electrocatalytic activity, the key step is to build appropriate electron synergy between rare earth species and different lively metals in the shape of f-d or f-d-p orbital coupling [19-21]. Generally, there are two methods to enhance the activity of rare earth catalysts. First of all, the engineering design of the surface properties of adsorption sites is usually called geometric effect. Second, the electronic properties of elements are changed by ligand effect or strain effect. The direct interaction between elements is called ligand effect, it changes the electronic properties of the alloy to affect the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediate, thus improving the ORR performance. When the elements in the alloy layer rearrange, resulting in alloy compression/expansion, strain effect will occur. The adsorption energy of reaction substances is low due to compression (favorable for reaction kinetics), while the adsorption energy of reactive substances may be high due to expansion (hindering reaction kinetics) [22,23]. 3 Precious metal composite rare earth catalyst 3.1 Pt composite rare earth catalyst Alloying of rare earth elements can enable precious metal alloys to have good surface reaction kinetics and adjustable reaction activity. In addition, it is assembled with Fe7-Ce1@GSL-800 cathode catalyst has excessive height energy density, excessive particular potential and fantastic lengthy cost discharge durability as shown in (Fig. 7 ). Transition metal oxides (TMOs) play an important role in the development of several key sustainable technologies. Due to their unusual electrical structure, including unfilled valence layer 3d orbitals and loss of unpaired single electrons, they are particularly susceptible to the influence of ORR and can typically improve electrochemical processes [88]. So Kang et al. [89] prepared by in-situ polymerization and high-temperature pyrolysis SmFeO x @NC. During this period, the model used to be silica substrate with excessive ground proximity, which had the conductivity of the organized catalyst more desirable and a very impressive shape. Subsequently, Kang et al. [90] efficiently synthesized a brilliant catalyst SmFeO x @NC-7, with decreased overpotential and expanded kinetic overall performance by using the usage of the interplay between bimetallic oxides and C3N4. As the air cathode of the zinc-air battery, it has a super-energy density of 90 mW cm−2, an ideal cycle balance, an excessive specific capacity of 540 mA hg−1, and an open-circuit voltage of 1.423 V. The cycle time is longer than that of precious metals, thus obtaining better stability. 4.2 Co or Ni composite rare earth catalyst Compounds containing Co/Ni, in especial cobalt/nickel metal oxides, due to its low cost, high soil density, rich variable price, comparable catalytic activity and stability, it is considered as a feasible substitute for noble metal catalysts in power plants. The Ni CeO2/rGO nanocomposite electrocatalyst synthesized by one-step microwave hydrothermal method in literature showed enhanced ORR activity [91]. It was found that under alkaline conditions, NiCo2O4 materials with spinel structure showed superior electrochemical activity to ORR than pure NiO or Co3O4 materials [92]. Therefore, Wang et al. [93] adopted two-step hydrothermal method to synthesize flower like NiCo2O4/CeO2 as an excellent ORR electrocatalytic catalyst, which is obviously superior to NiCo2O4 nano sheets or CeO2 nanospheres. It can even correspond to the alkaline electrolyte Pt/C (20 wt.%) sold on the market. Li et al. [94] synthesized La2O3/NiM NCNT (M = Fe, Co). The prepared La2O3/NiFe NCNT show superior ORR and OER activities. The reason is that NCNT provides electron transport channel and La2O3 can prevent the aggregation of alloy nanoparticles. In order to compensate for the shortcomings of weak activity and low conductivity of a single transition metal catalyst, a new type of acetylene black (AB) supported La2O3-Co/AB catalyst was prepared using a composite synthesis strategy based on rare earth (RE) doped zeolite imidazole skeleton 67 (ZIF-67) [95]. The synthesis steps are shown in the (Fig. 8 ). It can be seen from the Fig. 8a and b that the after doping rare earth, ZIF-67′s native structure can still be maintained. The slight attenuation of the strength indicates that the crystallinity decreases, indicating that the incorporation of rare earth may produce more defects. The Co peak gradually broadens and diminishes as La and AB are added. It demonstrates how the inclusion of acetylene black and rare earth elements will drastically alter the size distribution of Co, hence influencing its catalytic efficiency. From the Co 2p XPS spectrum in (Fig. 8c), both the La2O3 Co/NC and La2O3 Co/AB catalysts exhibit typical peaks of Co3+ in the Co 2p XPS spectrum. However only La2O3-Co/AB exhibits characteristic peaks of Co2+, confirming the electron transfer between Co species and AB. Also, neither of the two catalysts showed the typical peak of Co0, which could be attributed to the high concentration of CoN x species and the presence of cobalt oxides. The high resolution La 3d spectral division was used to demonstrate the existence of La3+ species (Fig. 8d). The development of the La-ZIF-67 crystal is hampered and the exposing of active sites is encouraged by the distinct coordination forms of La and Co. The catalyst's stability is increased by the La2O3 in the pyrolysis byproduct. The introduction of AB provides abundant anchor points to facilitate the formation of heterojunction and electron transfer at the interface. Bai et al. [96] designed the layered lanthanum carbonate (La2O2CO3) as a shape orientation template obtained from ZIF-67 to control carbon-based nanostructures. From the height function alternation of XPS curve, we can see the chemical interaction between CO3 2− factor in lanthanide compounds and Co atom in carbon-based nanostructures. With the combination growing on the surface of layered lanthanum carbonate without delay, the chemical closed contact between the two phases helps to form covalent Co[CO2]2−. The formed Co[CO2]2− bond can cause Co2+ ions to meet accidentally in the Co (II)N4 coordination and form a planar structure. This plane shape can promote the axial adsorption capacity of high-energy O2 on the uncoated Co (II) atom, which can enhance the ORR rate. The rare earth element Ce synthesized by Wu et al. [97] regulates the Co site. Theoretical calculations have shown that Ce single atoms have stronger vacancy binding energy than Co single atoms. This makes the single atom Co active site easy to use Ce@NC group substitution. The introduction of moderate Ce significantly increases the distance between Co single atom active sites, effectively dispersing them. The uniform dispersion of Co single atomic sites contributes to the improvement of catalyst performance. Li et al. [98] created a novel Sm2O3-Co/NEC300J carbon coupling rare earth Sm doped ZIF-67 encapsulating structure. Due to the powerful synergistic effect of Sm2O3 and Co, the addition of Sm2O3 considerably increased the electrocatalytic performance of ORR. Liu et al. [99] prepared a brand-new bifunctional catalyst (NiY/C@Co/C) generated from a bimetallic MOF based on rare earths. The stability and reaction rate of ORR and OER are enhanced due to the stable NiY/C nanorod matrix, while the nanoparticle derived from ZIF-67 is attached to the surface of the nanorod, which increases the nitrogen doping quantity and improves the ORR performance. The catalytic rate is increased by the electron transfer channel that NiY/C@Co/Y2O3 in C offers. Li et al. [100] prepared Gd2O3 Co/NG using a sol gel assisted strategy, and proved that adding Gd2O3 to metal Co's electrocatalytic performance for ORR can be greatly enhanced. After the introduction of high valence Gd2O3 into Co, the charge is redistributed at the engineering interface of Gd2O3/Co, resulting in more oxygen vacancies and optimizing the electronic structure of the catalyst surface. DFT calculation results are in good agreement with experimental observation results, which proves that the combination of OOH * and OH * on Gd2O3-Co surface is more balanced. When used as a cathode for zinc air batteries, Gd2O3-Co/NG has a power density of 114.3 mW cm−2, an energy density of 892.7 Wh kgZn −1, and excellent recoverability (over 160 cycles at 10 mA cm−2). 4.3 Other transition metal composite rare earth catalysts Meng et al. [101] successfully prepared a mesoporous aluminosilicate zeolite (ZSM-5) nanocomposite material SnCe ZSM co anchored with SnO2 and CeO2 nanoparticles (3–5 nm) through electrostatic interaction, in order to improve the electrocatalytic activity of HOR and ORR under alkaline electrolytes. When the particle size is small enough (<3 nm), SnO2 nanoparticles have Pt like catalytic activity, which is beneficial for HOR activity. The unique oxygen storage/release ability of CeO2 rich in oxygen vacancies can greatly promote O2 adsorption and improve ORR performance. Therefore, SnO2 and CeO2 on the skeleton of mesoporous ZSM-5 support with hierarchical pore structure are expected to greatly promote the exposure of Active site and accelerate the catalytic reaction. In particular, in the designed SnCe-ZSM composite, there is a Synergistic catalysis effect between the Active site of the SnO2/CeO2 species and the mesoporous ZSM-5 carrier, which leads to the optimal adjustment of the electronic interaction and charge redistribution at the interface junction of the three components. Compared with the ZSM-5 anchored by a single SnO2 or CeO2 nanoparticles in alkaline solution, the obtained HOR and ORR performance and the zinc air battery activity are greatly enhanced. The strong electronic interaction between MnOOH and CeO2 at the heterogeneous interface promotes internal electron transfer. There is a slight negative shift in the d-band center of the Mn site, resulting in faster electron transfer rate and higher conductivity. The acceleration of charge transfer optimizes the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby promoting the kinetics of oxygen reduction. The bimetallic oxide nanoparticles showed the same redox activity as Pt/C, and shows exceptional stability, performance and energy density. The synergistic effect of bimetallic oxide nanoparticles and the peculiar electronic layer arrangement of rare earth leads to excellent test performance [106]. 5 Nonmetallic element doped rare earth catalyst It has been found that apart from metallic elements, doping non-metallic elements can well improve ORR performance by improving the conductivity of rare earth species, adjusting the electronic structure and optimizing the adsorption strength of intermediate products. 5.1 N and C doping Carbon materials are promising catalytic materials because of their high conductivity, controllability and stability [107]. [108] prepared cerium carbide embedded in nitrogen doped carbon (CeC x NC). Meanwhile, more electron rich Se sites promote the adsorption of key intermediates, which leads to the optimal performance of ORR on CeSe DAs/NC. This study provides a new perspective for utilizing keyless remote coordination microenvironment engineering to modulate the electronic structure of DACs for efficient electrocatalysis. 6 Rare earth-based perovskite oxide Perovskite type oxides (ABO3) have the advantages of low cost, easy synthesis, and environmental friendliness. They also have unique defect structures and oxygen vacancy channels. The surface can provide a large number of reactive sites, which is a potential ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst [133-136]. The A site and B site ions are usually rare earth metal ions (the order of catalytic activity of common elements at A site is La > Pr > Nd > Sm > Gd) and transition metal ions (the order of catalytic activity of common elements at B site is Mn > Ni > Fe) [137,138]. At present, perovskite composite oxides are mainly modified from four aspects: A-site doping, B-site doping, A-site doping, B-site doping and carbon recombination, in order to obtain cathode catalytic materials with high catalytic activity for metal-air batteries. In the research on the doping of perovskite A site, Hao et al. [139] synthesized a series of perovskite with different Sm content through the sol–gel method, La1− x Sm x MnO3 (x = 0.4). XPS analysis confirmed that Sm doping can adjust the oxygen vacancy concentration and Mn4+/Mn3+ratio of the catalyst. DFT results show that the improvement of catalytic performance is due to the correction of Mn 3d and O 2p band centers, which may lead to an appropriate increase in the adsorption energy of intermediates, thus promoting the ORR and OER kinetic processes at the catalyst interface. The specific electronic configuration of Sm in the lattice reduces the grain boundary energy, slows down the grain growth and inhibits the Oswald maturation, thus making the catalyst show high stability. Xu et al. [140] and others successfully synthesized LSCFN perovskite with different amount of A-site defects, and found that A-site defects do not change the crystal structure of perovskite. The oxygen vacancy in the lattice is designed by adjusting the A-site defect, which controls the oxidation state of the surface transition metal ions, and effectively regulates the metal oxygen covalent and highly oxidized oxygen species. These structural adjustments are helpful to improve the electron transfer number and overall electrocatalytic activity of A-site defective LSCFN catalyst for ORR in alkaline solution. Based on the relatively small amount of hydroperoxide formed, it is found that ORR follows the 4-electron transfer path, which can explain the improved kinetics. This enhanced ORR kinetics extends the use of LSCFN as a cathode catalyst in aluminum air batteries. The discharge voltage performance of LSCFN is studied as shown in the figure. With the increase of A-site defects, the discharge voltage of LSCFN perovskite increases at different current densities. The increase of catalytic activity with higher A-site deletion is caused by the generation of oxygen vacancies, which can promote the diffusion of oxygen and electrolytes to the active sites. Obviously, the proper A-vacancy in LSFFN perovskite has a profound influence on ensuring its effective electrocatalytic ORR activity. This also shows the improved performance of A-vacancy perovskite catalyst. A-site doping affects the number of oxygen species converted from lattice oxygen to surface oxygen [141-143], which is crucial to improve catalyst activity [144,145]. 7 Conclusion and outlook In recent years, people have been working hard to develop and design cheaper and resource-rich nanomaterials to replace noble metals for oxygen reduction catalysis. These include metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, metal carbides, metal nitrides, MNC and heteroatom doped carbon, which have been widely developed by researchers with strenuous efforts. Rare earth-based catalysts have become an anticipating backup material for ORR catalysts in renewable energy conversion technology on account of their unusual physical and chemical characteristics. In this paper, the most important research on improving the property of rare earth catalysts through doping metal/non-metal elements in recent years is summarized, including ORR performance of noble metal element doping, non-noble metal element doping, non-metallic element doping, perovskite etc. It was found that some studies involved effects of surface, crystal structure, defect type, doping, as shown in Table 1 , to alloying and composite of ORR catalyst on its performance. In precious metal composition catalysts, alloy elements affect the electronic structure of surface atoms by ligation effect or tensile and compression elongation, thereby regulating catalytic activity. The precious metal composite rare earth catalyst has the same redox activity as Pt/C and has well stability, energy density and performance. This remarkable property is due to the synergistic influence on metal oxide nanoparticles and the distinctive structure of rare earth electronic layer. Experimental results have shown that rare earths exhibit binding energy and full width potential energy dependent displacement with other modified metals, with a maximum displacement of half, indicating successful coverage and conversion of oxygen intermediates in the ORR process. Theoretical calculations indicate that the metal-O-RE unit sites constructed by rare earths and modified metals are coupled through gradient orbitals of metal 3d-O2p-rare earth 4f, resulting in metal −3d having narrow bands and appropriate band positions. The narrowband behavior of the metal-O-RE unit sites allows for ideal s/p bond mixing between metal sites and oxygen intermediates, providing flexible binding strength for oxygen intermediates and breaking the scaling relationship between * OOH and * OH, making them closer to optimal conditions. The addition of rare earth metals in non-metallic composite rare earth catalysts will leads to an increase in the amount of disordered carbon and the formation of more defects in the carbon, which is conducive to obtaining more active sites and highlighting the electrocatalytic property. The ORR activity of the system is enhanced by the synergistic influence between rare earth and hetero-atom. In calcium titanium minerals, the increase of catalytic activity with higher A-site deletion is caused by the generation of oxygen vacancies, which can promote the diffusion of oxygen and electrolyte to the active site. In terms of application, the power density of metal air batteries assembled using rare-earth-based catalysts is currently very high, reaching up to 209.2 mW cm−2, which is much higher than commercial Pt/C, and has high rate discharge performance and cycling charging and discharging ability. Its sustainable and stable cycling charging and discharging for 80 h is more than four times that of commercial Pt/C batteries. But the prepared ORR catalyst can be tested in more metal air cells or fuel cells to obtain performance that is closer to practical applications. The proposed catalysts are only limited to bimetallic catalysts, and there are few tri-metal catalysts. Taking advantage of the feature that polynuclear metal coordination complexes or cluster compounds contain multiple metal atoms, it may be easier to synthesize or more simples to synthesize multi-component rare earth catalysts. However, the theoretical research on performance enhancement is few and incomplete. Therefore, in order to better explore the catalytic mechanism of atomic structure, it is very important to develop and research high-precision instruments. If these problems are solved, it will lead to a breakthrough in ORR catalyst. CRediT authorship contribution statement Xiao Man: Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis. coredata.dc:description: Rare earth (RE) metals have special 4f shell electronic configuration and special physical and chemical properties. Therefore, rare-earth-based catalysts are extensive used in the electrochemical cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells. However, the low conductivity and low active site density of these catalysts limit their effective application in electrochemistry. The results show that the oxygen reduction activity and stability of rare-earth-based catalysts can be significantly improved by controlling the electronic structure and spatial configuration of active sites through doping of metal/nonmetal elements. In this paper, the main research work on metal/nonmetallic element doping to improve the performance of rare earth-based-catalysts in recent years was reviewed, including noble metal element doping, non-noble metal element doping, non-metallic element doping, perovskite and so on. The paper further summarized and pointed out the problems and challenges faced by rare-earth-based catalysts, and looked forward to their development prospects and future research directions.
